Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Dharmaká¹£ema of the Northern Liang, from Central India
Miscellaneous Chapter, Continued
Good sons!
If there are people who are stingy and do not give in terms of their body, life, and wealth, this is called stinginess.

Protecting and being stingy, the mind of not giving does not arise, not feeling pity, waiting for the field of blessings, seeking the field of blessings, having obtained, seeking faults, seeing wealth as difficult to obtain, suffering for it;
Or saying there are no fruits, no giving, no recipients;

Protecting the mind of wife, children, relatives, and so forth, accumulating wealth to seek fame, seeing much giving rise to joy, regarding wealth as permanent, this is called the stain of stinginess.
This stain can defile the minds of sentient beings. For this reason, one is not even able to give to others' things, let alone one's own things?

The wise practice giving not for the sake of repaying kindness, not for the sake of seeking things, not for the sake of protecting and cherishing stingy and greedy people, not for the sake of being born in the heavens and among humans to experience happiness, not for the sake of spreading good fame to the outside world, not for the sake of fearing the suffering of the three evil paths, not for the sake of others seeking, not for the sake of surpassing others, not for the sake of losing wealth, not for the sake of having much, not for the sake of not using, not for the sake of family rules, not for the sake of intimacy.

The wise practice giving out of compassion, in order to bring happiness to others, in order to cause others to give rise to the mind of giving, in order to follow the path practiced by the sages, in order to destroy all afflictions, and in order to enter nirvana and cut off existence.
Good son!
Bodhisattvas' giving is far removed from four evils:
First, breaking precepts; second, doubt and confusion; third, wrong views; fourth, stinginess.
They are also free from five dharmas:

First, when giving, do not select those with virtue or those without virtue; second, when giving, do not speak of good or evil; third, when giving, do not choose social class; fourth, when giving, do not despise the recipient; fifth, when giving, do not speak harshly or scold.
There are also three things that, after giving, do not attain supreme and wonderful rewards:
First, having initially generated the intention to give much, later give little; second, select inferior things and give them to others; third, after having given, the mind gives rise to regret.
Good man!
There are also eight things that, after giving, do not accomplish the supreme fruit:

First, after giving, seeing the faults of the recipient; second, when giving, the mind is not impartial; third, after giving, seeking to control the recipient; fourth, after giving, delighting in self-praise; fifth, saying there is nothing and then giving; sixth, after giving, speaking harshly and scolding; seventh, after giving, seeking twice the return; eighth, after giving, giving rise to doubt.
Such a donor will not be able to draw near to the buddhas and sages.
If one gives with complete color, fragrance, taste, and touch, this is called pure giving;
If one is able to give with wealth obtained in accordance with the Dharma, this is called pure giving;
Contemplating that wealth is impermanent and cannot be kept for long, and practicing giving, this is called pure giving;
Practicing giving in order to destroy afflictions, this is called pure giving;
Giving for the sake of purifying one's own mind, this is called pure giving;

If one contemplates who gives, who is the recipient, what things are given, for what reasons they are given, and what fruits are obtained from the causes and conditions of giving - in this way, giving is the twelve sense bases. The recipient, the giver, the causes and conditions, and the fruits and rewards are all the twelve sense bases. One who is able to contemplate in this way and practice giving is called one who practices pure giving.

When practicing giving, one should give rise to a joyful mind towards the field of blessings. Just as the fields of blessings seek the merits they desire, I also seek them in the same way without rest. When giving to one's wife, children, relatives, and servants, one should give with a compassionate mind. When giving to the poor, it is to destroy their suffering.

When giving, one should not seek worldly rewards. One should give without arrogance, with a gentle and tender mind, free from all attachments, and for the sake of seeking unsurpassed liberation. One should give deeply contemplating the many faults and offenses in the cycle of birth and death, and give without discriminating between fields of blessings and non-fields of blessings.
If one is able to practice giving in this way, the rewards will follow this person like a calf following its mother.
If one seeks rewards for giving, it is no different from bartering.
Just as one tills the fields and plants crops for one's own life, one reaps the fruits according to the seeds sown;
The donor, having given, is also like this, and obtains the rewards of blessings according to what was given.
Just as the recipient of the offering obtains life, complexion, strength, peace, and eloquence upon receiving it, the donor also obtains these five rewards;

If one gives to animals, one obtains a hundredfold reward, if one gives to those who violate precepts, one obtains a thousandfold reward, if one gives to those who uphold precepts, one obtains a hundred thousand rewards, if one gives to non-Buddhists who have severed desires, one obtains a million rewards, if one gives to those who are heading towards the path, one obtains a thousand koá¹­i rewards, if one gives to a srotÄpanna, one obtains immeasurable rewards, if one gives to one who is heading towards the state of saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin, it is also of immeasurable rewards, up to becoming a buddha, it is also of immeasurable rewards.
Good man!
I now explain this for you, in order to distinguish the various fields of blessings, saying that one can obtain a hundredfold reward up to immeasurable rewards.
If one can give with utmost sincerity and great compassion to animals, and give to the buddhas with a focused and respectful mind, the blessings are exactly equal and no different.

As for the term hundredfold, it means that if one gives longevity, appearance, strength, peace, and eloquence to others, the donor will later obtain a hundredfold of each of longevity, appearance, strength, happiness, and eloquence;
up to immeasurable, it is also like this.
Therefore, I say in the sÅ«tras:
I give to ÅšÄriputra, and ÅšÄriputra also gives to me, but I obtain much, not ÅšÄriputra obtaining much merit.
Some people say that if the recipient commits evil, the donor is also guilty, this is not so!
Why is it so?
When the donor gives, it is to relieve their suffering, not to create offenses. Therefore, the donor should obtain good results;
The recipient creates evil, and the offense belongs to them alone, not to the donor.

If the donor gives pure and wonderful things, they will later obtain a good appearance, be liked by people, have a good reputation spread far and wide, have their wishes fulfilled, be born into a noble family, and this is not considered evil. How can it be said that the donor commits an offense?

After the donor has given, they rejoice and do not regret it. They become close to good people, become wealthy and independent, are born into a noble family, obtain human and heavenly bliss up to the unsurpassed bliss, and are able to leave behind all afflictions and bonds. The donor obtains such wonderful fruits. How can it be said that they obtain an evil retribution?

If the donor can give with their own hands, they will be born into a high-ranking family, meet with good spiritual friends, have abundant wealth and treasures, and their retinue will be accomplished. They will be able to use and give, and all beings will delight in seeing them. Having seen them, they will respect, honor, and praise them. The donor will receive such rewards. How can it be said that they will receive bad karmic retribution?

If the donor has already given pure things, by this cause and condition they will have abundant wealth and treasures, be born into a high-ranking family, have immeasurable retinue, have no physical illness or suffering, and have no mental worries or fears. Their wealth and possessions will not be harmed by kings, thieves, water, or fire. Even if they lose their wealth, they will not be sorrowful. Their body and mind will be at ease for immeasurable lives. How can it be said that they will receive bad karmic retribution?

If one gives with faith before giving, rejoices when giving, and is at ease after giving, and if one does not suffer when seeking, guarding, or using, if one gives clothing one attains the most wonderful form, if one gives food one attains unsurpassed strength, if one gives lamps one attains pure and wonderful eyes, if one gives vehicles one's body experiences comfort, if one gives dwellings one lacks nothing in one's needs. The donor thus obtains such good rewards, so how can it be said that one obtains an evil result?
Furthermore, if a donor has already given to the Buddha, whether it is used or not, the karmic retribution is already fixed.
Giving to people and the Sangha has two kinds of blessings:
One arises from use, the other arises from acceptance.
Why is this?
When the donor gives, they themselves break through stinginess. When the recipient uses it, they break through the stinginess of others. Therefore, it is said that blessings arise from use.

Moreover, from the recipient, the one who uses can turn to using, and the Sangha can increase and grow. After giving, one does not seek worldly rewards, and does not give with the ability to give rise to afflictions as the cause. Therefore, one can attain the unsurpassed pure fruit, called nirvana.

If someone can make a vow day after day, to give food to others first and then eat themselves, if they violate this vow, they swear to pay the Buddha's things, and if they violate it, they feel ashamed;
If they do not violate it, it is the cause and condition of subtle wisdom. Such a giver is the best among all givers, and such a person is also called the supreme donor.
If one can give in accordance with the wishes of the seeker, this person will have their wishes fulfilled in countless future lives.
If one has a pure mind, wealth, and fields of blessings that are all pure, this person will attain immeasurable rewards.
If one provides clothing and food for one's wife, children, and servants, always giving with compassion and joy, in the future one will attain immeasurable blessings and virtues.
He also observed that in the fields and granaries, there were many rats and sparrows, damaging the grain and rice, and always felt compassion for them.
He further thought:
'These rats and sparrows depend on me to survive.'
Having thought this, he was joyful, without any thought of disturbance. Know that this person will obtain immeasurable blessings.

If one makes clothes, necklaces, rings, and other adornments for one's own body, and various utensils, and after making them, is joyful, and without using them oneself, gives them to others, this person will in the future obtain a wish-fulfilling tree.
If someone says that apart from giving, one can obtain good fruits, this is not possible;
that apart from wealth, there is giving, apart from the recipient, there is giving, and apart from stinginess, there is giving, this is also not possible.

If one does not seek to give, but gives when lacking, gives much when seeking little, gives good when seeking bad, teaches others to seek and give, or goes oneself to give, one should know that in the future one will obtain many treasure troves, and all non-treasures will transform into treasures.
Giving for the sake of play and laughter, giving to those not worthy of offerings, giving without believing in cause and effect - such giving is not called giving.
If one gives only to excellent fields of blessings, but does not enjoy constant giving, then when one obtains the fruits of retribution in the future, one will not enjoy giving.

If one gives and then gives rise to regret, or if one gives after taking things from others, then although one may obtain wealth and objects in the future, they will always be lost and not accumulate.
If one gives after harming one's relatives, then although one may obtain great rewards in the future, one's body will always be afflicted with illness and suffering.
If one first cannot make offerings to one's parents, troubles one's wife, children, and servants, and gives in distress, this is called an evil person, a nominal giver, not a true giver;

Such a giver is called merciless, not knowing gratitude, and this person in the future, although obtaining wealth and treasures, will always lose and not accumulate, not able to use it, and will have much illness and suffering.
If a person gives wealth in accordance with the Dharma, this person in the future will obtain immeasurable blessings, have wealth and be able to use it;

If there are those who do not give wealth in accordance with the Dharma, this person in the future, although obtaining the fruits of retribution, will always rely on others, and if others die, he will soon become poor.

A wise person deeply contemplates that the pleasures of humans, gods, and wheel-turning kings, although subtle and wonderful, are all impermanent. Therefore, when giving, one does not give for the sake of humans and gods.
Good son!
There are two kinds of giving:
First, giving of wealth, second, giving of the Dharma.
Material giving is called inferior, and giving of the Dharma is called superior.
What is giving of the Dharma?

If bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, or upÄsikÄs are able to teach others to be endowed with faith, precepts, generosity, much learning, and wisdom, or if they use paper and ink to have others copy or copy themselves the true canon of the TathÄgata, and then give it to others to read and recite, this is called giving of the Dharma.
Those who give in this way will obtain excellent superior form in the future without limit.

Why is this?ğŸ”½Because sentient beings hear the Dharma and eliminate hateful thoughts, by this cause and condition, the giver will in the future, for innumerable lives, attain excellent form.ğŸ”½Because sentient beings hear the Dharma and have a compassionate mind and do not kill, by this cause and condition, the giver will in the future, for innumerable lives, attain a long lifespan.
Because sentient beings hear the Dharma and do not steal others' wealth, by this cause and condition, the giver will in the future, for innumerable lives, be rich with abundant treasures.

Sentient beings, having heard it, open their minds and happily give, and by this cause and condition, the donor in the future will attain great strength in innumerable lives.ğŸ”½Sentient beings, having heard the Dharma, eliminate all negligence, and by this cause and condition, the donor in the future will attain physical comfort in innumerable lives.
Sentient beings, having heard the Dharma, eliminate deluded thoughts, and by this cause and condition, the donor in the future will attain unobstructed eloquence in innumerable lives.
Sentient beings, having heard the Dharma, give rise to faith without doubt, and by this cause and condition, the donor in the future will have clear faith in innumerable lives;
precepts, giving, hearing, and wisdom are also like this.
Therefore, the gift of Dharma surpasses the gift of material things.

Some say that if the child cultivates wholesome dharmas, the father does unwholesome deeds, and because the child cultivates wholesomeness, it causes the father not to fall into the three evil destinies, that is not so!
Why is it so?
Because the actions of body, speech, and mind are each different.
If the father has died and fallen into the realm of hungry ghosts, if the son performs meritorious deeds on his behalf, it should be known that the father will receive the benefits;
if he has been reborn in the heavens, he will not think of anything in the human realm at all.
Why is this?
Because in the heavens, he has attained supreme and wonderful treasures.
If he has entered hell, his body will suffer torment, and he will not have the leisure to think of anything, therefore he will not receive the benefits;
the same is so for animals and humans.
If one says, Why can only hungry ghosts receive the benefits?
Because due to their past greed and stinginess, they fell into the realm of hungry ghosts;
having become hungry ghosts, they always regret their past faults and think of wanting to obtain [the benefits], therefore they can receive them.
If the one for whom the meritorious deeds are performed has been reborn in another realm, but his other relatives have fallen into the realm of hungry ghosts, they will all receive the benefits.
Therefore, the wise should diligently perform meritorious deeds for the sake of hungry ghosts.

If one gives clothing, food, dwellings, bedding, and other necessities to Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the poor and needy, and makes prayers for their blessings, by the power of the causes and conditions of this giving and prayer, those who have fallen into the realm of hungry ghosts will attain great power, and will obtain according to their giving.
Why is this?
Because the place of birth is like this.

The food of hungry ghosts is not the same - some eat pus, some eat feces, some eat blood-stained vomit, snot, and spittle. Having obtained this giving, all transform into the most wonderful colors and flavors.
Although they give the dregs and juices of impurities to those who should eat, they are still protected and are not allowed to eat;
In this way, the giver also attains blessings and virtues.
Why is this?
Because the mind of the giver is compassionate and pitiful.
If there is a sacrifice, who is the recipient?
According to the place of the sacrifice, it becomes the recipient:
If they are near a forest, the tree spirits receive it. Houses, rivers, springs, wells, mountains, forests, and mounds are also like this.
After these people have made offerings, they also obtain blessings and virtues.
Why is this?
It is because it causes the recipients to give rise to a joyful mind.
These offerings and blessings can protect one's body and wealth.
If it is said that killing living beings in sacrifice obtains blessings, this is not so!
Why is this?
One does not see in the world that planting sandalwood seeds produces an agarwood tree, or that ending the lives of many beings obtains blessings and virtues!
If one wishes to make offerings, one should use incense, flowers, milk, curd, ghee, and medicine.
For the sake of the deceased, there are three times:
the spring season is two months, the summer season is five months, and the autumn season is nine months.

If a person gives others houses, bedding, medicine, gardens, wells, cows, sheep, elephants, horses, and various necessities, and after giving them away, their life ends, the person's blessings and virtues will arise according to the duration of use of the given objects. These blessings and virtues will always follow the person, like a shadow following a form.
Some say that after death, they are lost, but this is not so!
Why is it so?
The objects are lost when they are destroyed or not used, not when one's life ends.
If an ordained person imitates lay people and abandons food and drink on the days of the year, it is because of worldly customs, not because of truth;
It is also because of faith in worldly and transcendent teachings.
If one is able to always happily give whatever one's family has, good or bad, it is called giving everything.
If one gives one's body parts, wife and children, and cherished possessions to others, it is called inconceivable giving.

If there are evil people, those who violate precepts, enemies, those who do not know gratitude and righteousness, those who forcefully beg and demand, those with great power, those who are good at cursing, those who become angry after receiving, those who deceptively display good appearances, and those who are greatly wealthy and noble, giving to these eleven types of people is called inconceivable giving.
Good man!
All giving has three roots:
Giving to the poor out of pity;
Giving to enemies without seeking repayment;
Giving to the virtuous with a joyful and respectful mind.
Good man!

If a person has much wealth and makes offerings to the Three Jewels for countless years, although they may attain immeasurable merit and rewards, it is not as good as encouraging others to cooperate and work together.
If a person looks down on small things and bad things, is ashamed, and is unwilling to give, this person will increase poverty and suffering in future lives.

If two people give together, with equal wealth, field of blessings, and giving mind, the fruits they obtain will be no different;ğŸ”½If the wealth and mind are equal, but the field of blessings is superior, the reward obtained will be superior;
If the field and mind are inferior, but the wealth is superior, the fruit obtained will also be superior;
If the field and wealth are inferior, but the giving mind is superior, the fruit obtained will also be superior;
If the field and wealth are superior, but the giving mind is inferior, the fruit obtained will not be as good.
Good man!
The wise do not give for the sake of rewards.
Why is this?
Because they know for certain that this cause will definitely bring forth a result.
If a person is without compassion, does not know gratitude, does not covet the merits possessed by sages, is stingy with wealth and life, and has a strong attachment, such a person is unable to give.

The wise deeply contemplate that when all sentient beings seek wealth and goods, they do not spare their lives. Having obtained wealth and goods, they are able to give them away to others. One should know that such people are able to give up their lives.
If a person is stingy and unable to let go of wealth, one should know that such a person also cherishes their life.
If one gives up one's life to seek wealth and goods and then gives them away, one should know that such a person is a great benefactor.
If a person obtains wealth, greedily cherishes it, and does not give it away, one should know that this is the seed of poverty in future lives.
Therefore, I say in the sutras:
Among the four continents, the people of JambudvÄ«pa have three things that surpass others: first, they are courageous and strong; second, they have a good memory; third, their conduct is pure.

Not seeing the karmic retribution, one is able to preemptively create causes, not sparing one's life. Having obtained wealth, one is able to destroy stinginess. Having given, one thinks of giving again. Having already given, one's mind does not give rise to regret. One is also able to discern between fields of merit and non-fields of merit. This is called being courageous and strong.
Good man!
Giving rise to regret after giving is caused by three things:
First, greed and attachment to wealth; second, consulting and following wrong views; third, seeing the faults of the recipient.
There are also three things:
First, fearing others' scolding; second, fearing the suffering of exhausting one's wealth; third, seeing others' suffering and distress after giving.
Good man!
The wise person does not give rise to a regretful mind at the three times. There are also three things:
First, clearly believing in cause and effect; second, closely associating with good friends; third, not being attached to wealth.
Those who believe in cause and effect have two things:
First, listening to the Dharma from others; second, contemplating it within oneself.
Being close to good friends also has two aspects:
First, deep faith; second, wisdom.
Not being greedy for wealth also has two aspects:
First, contemplating impermanence; second, not being in control.
Good man!
If the donor is able to observe in this way and practice giving in this way, know that this person is able to fully practice the perfection of giving.
Therefore, I have previously said:
There is giving that is not a perfection, there is a perfection that is not giving, there is that which is both giving and a perfection, and there is that which is neither giving nor a perfection.
Good man!
Wisdom is of three kinds:
First, being able to give away external things; second, giving away external and internal things; third, after giving away external and internal things, further transforming sentient beings.
What is transforming?
Seeing the poor, one should first say:
'Can you take refuge in the Three Jewels?
Do you accept the precepts of the fast?
' If they say they can, first bestow the Three Refuges and the precepts of the fast, and then give them things;
If they say they cannot, they should be told again:
'If you cannot, can you follow me in saying that all dharmas are impermanent, without self, and that nirvana is quiescent extinction?'
If they say they can, teach them again, and after teaching, give them things;
If they say, 'I can say these two things now, but I cannot say that all dharmas are without self,' they should be told again:
'If you cannot say that all dharmas are without self, can you say that all dharmas are without intrinsic nature?'
If they say they can, teach them again and then give them things.
If you can teach like this first and then give, you are called a great donor.
Good man!
If you can teach and transform sentient beings like this, without discriminating between enemies and friends, you are called a great donor.
Good man!
When the wise have wealth and possessions, they should practice giving in this way;
If they are without wealth, they should also teach others who have wealth to make this giving;
If other benefactors already know this Dharma and do not need to be taught, they should go and assist them with their physical strength.

If they are destitute and have nothing, they should recite medical prescriptions and various spells, seek money, medicine, and tonics, and give them to those in need, wholeheartedly tending to the sick, nursing and treating them, and encouraging those with wealth to gather various medicines:
Whether pills, powders, or various tonics.

Having mastered medical prescriptions, they should go everywhere to tend to the sick, diagnose the illnesses according to the prescriptions, and treat them according to the locations of the illnesses.

When treating illnesses, they should skillfully know the methods. Although they may be in impure places, they should not give rise to feelings of disgust. They should know when the illness is increasing and when it is decreasing;
They are also able to skillfully know that such food and medicine can increase the suffering of illness, and know that such food and medicine can cure the suffering of illness.
If the sick person seeks food and medicine that increases illness, they should skillfully speak appropriately, and should not say there is none;
if they say there is none, it may increase the severity of suffering.

If they know the person will definitely die, they should not say they will die, but should teach them to take refuge in the Three Jewels, to contemplate the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and to diligently make offerings;
they should tell them that all the suffering of illness is due to unwholesome causes and conditions from the past, and that they will receive this painful retribution, and now they should repent.
If the sick person hears this, they may become angry and speak evil words, but they should remain silent and not respond, nor should they abandon them;
although they may still attend to them, they should be careful not to demand gratitude. After they recover, they should still look after them, fearing that the illness may return later.
If they see that they have fully recovered and are as healthy as before, they should rejoice in their hearts and not seek gratitude or reward;
If they die, you should bury them and console their relatives and friends with the Dharma.

Do not give people food and medicine that will increase their illness. If they recover, you may accept the gifts they joyfully offer. Having accepted them, you should pass them on to other needy people.
If you can care for and treat the sick in this way, know that such a person is a great benefactor, truly seeking the path to unsurpassed enlightenment.
Good man!

When wise people seek enlightenment, even if they have many treasures, they should still read and recite such medical prescriptions, build hospitals, and provide food, drink, medicine, and other necessities for the sick.
On uneven roads, level them to make them wide, remove thorns, stones, excrement, and other impurities, and provide boards, ladders, rafters, and ropes as needed on dangerous sections.
On the open road, he dug wells, planted fruit trees and forests, and repaired springs and ponds. In places without trees, he erected poles for animals to tie to and rest under.
He built guest houses equipped with all necessary items such as jars, basins, candles, beds, and bedding.

In places with foul-smelling streams, he built bridges and ferries. At river crossings, he provided bridges and boats. For those unable to cross, he went himself to help them. For the elderly, young, and weak without strength, he personally carried them across.
By the road, he built stupas and planted flowering and fruit trees.
Seeing those in fear, he would immediately rescue and hide them, using both material things and kind words to comfort and reassure the captors.
If he saw a practitioner approaching a dangerous place, he would go ahead to help them pass through the danger;
if he saw someone who had lost their land or gone bankrupt, he would provide them with what they needed and comfort them with kind words.
When they are tired from traveling far, you should wash and bathe them, massage their hands and feet, and offer them beds and seats;
if there are no beds or seats, you should spread grass for them.
In hot weather, use fans and clothes to shade them, and in cold weather offer them fire, clothing, and warmth, either doing it yourself or instructing others to do so.
In buying and selling and bartering, teach them to rely on fairness, not greedy for small profits, and not deceiving each other.
When seeing travelers, show them the right and wrong paths - the right path is said to have plenty of water, grass, and no thieves - and explain that the wrong path has many difficulties.
When seeing people whose shoes, clothes, and alms bowls are worn out and broken, immediately sew and mend them, wash and dye them, and fumigate them;
if there are problems with rats, snakes, bedbugs, or poisonous insects, you can help get rid of them.
Offer people what they need, such as nail clippers, ear picks, and hooks, and sew, wash, and mend the belongings of the saá¹ƒgha, such as bedding and seats.
On the toilet, place clean water, soap beans, and clean ash and soil, etc.
If you make your own clothes and bowls, first offer them to the Buddha, and also have your parents, teachers, and preceptors use them first, and then use them yourself;
If you offer them to the Buddha, redeem them with flowers and incense.
Whatever you eat, first give it to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, and then eat it yourself.

When you see those who have come from afar, speak gently to them, give them clean water to wash their bodies, and rub oil on their feet - fragrant flowers, toothbrushes, soap beans, ash and soil, fragrant oil, fragrant water, honey, vÄ«á¹‡Äs, undergarments, and small clothes for those who apply oil.
After washing, again give various fragrant flowers, pills, powders, food, and water according to their needs;
Also give razors, water strainers, needles, thread, cloth, paper, pens, and ink, etc.
If one cannot always do so, one should give on the days of the precepts.
If one sees a blind person, one should take their hand and guide them with a cane;

if one sees someone suffering, who has lost their property, or whose parents have passed away, one should provide them with wealth, speak the Dharma well, comfort and admonish them, and skillfully explain the two fruits of afflictions and blessings.
Good man!
If one is able to cultivate such giving, one is called a pure donor.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
first, the lay; second, the monastic.
It is not difficult for the monastic bodhisattva to be a pure donor;
it is difficult for the lay bodhisattva to be a pure donor.
Why is this?
Because the lay person is bound by many evil conditions.
Chapter 20: The Pure Three Refuges, from the Sutra on UpÄsaka Precepts, says:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha previously said, 'When someone comes begging, one should first teach them to accept the Three Refuges, and then give to them.' For what reasons do they accept the Three Refuges?
What is meant by the Three Refuges?
Good man!
In order to destroy all suffering and eliminate afflictions, one accepts the Three Refuges in order to attain the unsurpassed bliss of cessation.
As for your question about what the Three Refuges are,
good man!
They are the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹ƒgha.
The Buddha is able to expound the causes for destroying afflictions and attaining true liberation.
The Dharma is precisely the true liberation that destroys the causes of afflictions.
The Saá¹ƒgha is those who receive and uphold the causes for destroying afflictions and attain true liberation.
Some say, 'If it is like this, then it is only one refuge,' but this is not so!
Why is it so?
